Sentencas: A major degradation mechanism in solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) is poisoning of the cathode by chromium from volatilization of the interconnect material.
Titulo: Effect of cathode and electrolyte transport properties on chromium poisoning in solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: The chromium deposition has been attributed to both chemical and electrochemical mechanisms.
Titulo: Effect of cathode and electrolyte transport properties on chromium poisoning in solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: For an electrochemical reaction, deposition can occur only where both ions and electrons are available, which, for a purely ionic conducting electrolyte and a purely electronic conducting cathode, can occur only at the three-phase gas-electrolyte-electrode interface.
Titulo: Effect of cathode and electrolyte transport properties on chromium poisoning in solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: However, the introduction of ionic conductivity into the cathode or electronic conductivity into the electrolyte can allow deposition to occur away from this three-phase interface, and thus alter its effect on the fuel cell performance.
Titulo: Effect of cathode and electrolyte transport properties on chromium poisoning in solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: In this paper, the chromium poisoning of SOFC cathodes is reviewed, with a focus on the effects of the transport properties of the cathode and electrolyte materials.
Titulo: Effect of cathode and electrolyte transport properties on chromium poisoning in solid oxide fuel cells
